title: Château de Saint-Aubin-du-Cormier
text:
Château de Saint-Aubin-du-Cormier is a medieval castle, built in the 13th century in the commune of <a href="Saint-Aubin-du-Cormier">Saint-Aubin-du-Cormier</a> in the département d'<a href="Ille-et-Vilaine">Ille-et-Vilaine</a> in <a href="Brittany">Brittany</a>.
Dismantled in 1490, only the donjon remains today. It was registered as a "<a href="monument%20historique">monument historique</a>" on 15 December 1926.
Location.
Château de Saint-Aubin is located near the forest of Rennes, where there was already a chapel dedicated to <a href="Albinus%20of%20Angers">Albinus of Angers</a>.
History.
In 1225, <a href="Peter%20I%2C%20Duke%20of%20Brittany">Peter I, Duke of Brittany</a> ordered the construction of a castle. The enceinte is quadrilateral and measures 100m by 30m with ten towers.
After the death of king <a href="Louis%20VIII%20of%20France">Louis VIII</a>, Peter I changed allegiance and fought for King <a href="Henry%20III%20of%20England">Henry III of England</a>. The French army under orders from Louis IX unsuccessfully attempted a siege in 1231, but Peter handed over the in 1234 when he submitted to the king of France.
During the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Breton%20Succession">War of Breton Succession</a>, the castle was taken by <a href="Charles%2C%20Duke%20of%20Brittany">Charles de Blois</a> in 1342 before it was handed over to <a href="John%20of%20Montfort">Jean IV de Montfort</a> in 1381. The castle was remodelled in 1430 and at the same time ramparts were built around the town.
The castle was dismantled in 1490 and abandoned.
